posts.name: Spencer
posts.cooked: Has anyone tried running SDS L4 modules with Neos on a full-weight (125lb inspection) robot? If so, how’d it go? We’ve seen it done with Krakens, but they have double the stall torque and we’re trying to spare spending $1500 to do the conversion.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
Neo 1650 is just colloquially called a Neo and the smaller is a Neo 550 in case people were confused at first like me. I was hoping they had suddenly introduced a new motor size and was confused/excited.

We don’t have the SDS swerve, but Max Swerve with Neo (1650) and Neo 550. It held up well and we were using the highest speed gearing by default. I don’t know if anything larger than the Neo 550 would be useful for steering. You don’t need extra steering power and extra will probably wear out the hardware faster. The power is needed on the propulsion motors so maybe look for ways to save on steering as well.

Our robot was under 100lbs without bumpers during inspection but we had a heavy duty aluminum chassis, climber, floor intake and shooter. Low and heavy for its size.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: We ran L4 Neo Mk4 last year and definitely felt the lack of acceleration, especially in autonomous movement. I imagine it can be good with Krakens, but top speed matters less than acceleration in nearly all drive cases.

posts.name: Luke
posts.cooked: I’m pretty sure the SDS modules are configured for two full size motors. I don’t have much to offer except a recommendation to get something faster than L1, which my team ordered on our first ever swerve modules and which are now annoyingly slow in every match. I think you could do something like neos for steering and krakens for drive, but that would require ordering a few extra gears in addition to what’s included.  I’m no expert, though, so don’t rely on this advice.

posts.name: Spencer
posts.cooked:
kingc95:

I was hoping they had suddenly introduced a new motor size and was confused/excited.

I changed the title and my post, sorry about giving you false hope that we had even more new motors.

@Amicus1 , did you have any problems with excessive wear?

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: We had a bunch of issues with the motors, but those were probably not related to the gearing choice.

Least expensive option to get more speed out of your current modules is the 16t pinion. We swapped from L1 on our first modules to L2 and it was a huge difference. We swapped to vortex with L2 this year and had great results. Tried the 16t pinion with L2 and the acceleration dropped dramatically. The L1 with 16t pinion will probably give you the best speed bump to cost ratio. You could swap to vortexes with solo adapters to save money and give time for the bugs to get worked out of the flex motor controllers (wish we would’ve done that first) here are the speed ratio screen shots i have clipped from sds Screenshot_20240214_101631_Chrome 1080×896 136 KB Screenshot_20240214_101452_Chrome 984×454 65.5 KB

Screenshot_20240214_101631_Chrome 1080×896 136 KB

Screenshot_20240214_101631_Chrome 1080×896 136 KB

Screenshot_20240214_101452_Chrome 984×454 65.5 KB

Screenshot_20240214_101452_Chrome 984×454 65.5 KB

Edit: sorry this is in reference to mk4i and you are running mk4. Still if the 16t pinion kit works on mk4 I recommend doing that. We plan on swapping to Krakens next year but were already invested in the REV system to swap this season. Our test robot is 111.5 lbs

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: My views are mine and mine alone

posts.custom_user_title: My views are mine and mine alone

posts.name: Isaac Wentland
posts.cooked: We ran Mk4 with L3 gearing and NEOs last year with a 115lb robot and as the driver I didn’t really have the acceleration I would have liked and the pushing power against defense. While NEOs with L4 is doable I would not recommend it at all. I personally believe top speed is important to a point but with such little torque that L4 gives with NEOs I would be worried you wouldn’t manage to get up to that top speed by the time you cross the field and would be overall slower. We are running Krakens with Mk4 L4 and I love the torque and speed that gives, and I would recommend if you can going for Krakens on L4 even though it is more expensive.

Regardless of which motors you use, if you’re committed to gearing your 125 lb robot with L4, you’re going to have to make a compromise somewhere on the spectrum of “poor acceleration” to “burning up batteries, breakers, connectors, and wires”. However much time you spend working on the swerve drive itself, spend several times as much work making sure that everything about your electrical system is in top-notch condition.
